abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Health Project in Oman. The
            project's objectives were to: (a) reduce mortality and
            morbidity, targeting the 300,000 inhabitants of the
            predominantly rural Batinah region; (b) strengthen
            Government's health planning and management capacity;
            and (c) strengthen the health care delivery system in
            support of the health sector strategy. Bank's
            performance was satisfactory. Borrower's performance
            was satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows:
            (i) the existing institutional arrangements and structure
            and the absorptive capacity of the Borrower and sector
            ministry must be assessed in detail with regard to
            implementation mechanisms and project management
            arrangements; (ii) in hindsight it would also have been
            useful to do an explicit stakeholder analysis; (iii)
            architectural designs for the clinics should have been
            agreed during appraisal and confirmed during negotiations;
            and (iv) the Bank should have been more insistent that the
            baseline survey was carried out as this was central to the
            monitoring and evaluation system.
